comment.narrative: Outcome 1: 1.1 Currently there is no integrated planning base for flood risk management in the Polog Region/Upper Vardar River Basin. Municipalities and national level institutions take individual, ad-hoc actions to control floods without consideration of changes in the risk to other communities. 1.2 There is no consistent long-term public financing of flood risk mitigation actions (only ad-hoc responses to disastrous events). Outcome 1: • Preparation of the feasibility study on Basin-Scale Sediment Management Options for the Polog Region • Facilitation of the process of establishment of the Joint Administrative Unit of the Polog region for Floods Risks Management and Environmental Protection • Support to mainstreaming DRR and urban resilience building priorities in the City of Tetovo GUP • Finalization of a consolidated national-level methodology for developing municipal flood management plans • Update of nine municipal flood management plans in line with the objectives of Upper Vardar River Basin’s FRMP
Outcome 3: • Development (or update) of design documentation for urban river management (Vardar, Gostivar; Vardar, Jegunovce, Bogovinjska River) • Launching of the urban runoff management study for Tetovo and Gostivar • Implementation of flood proofing options and green roofs for selected set of public buildings.

Outcome 1: - FRMP identified the most critical river sections in the basin when it comes to flood risk for which there are limited management options (e.g., limitations imposed by urbanization in the floodplains/river corridors). These interventions are considered the highest priority for the authorities having in mind the magnitude of existing risks. At the same time, these are among the most investment-heavy measures. For part of these interventions, municipalities have already prepared detailed technical documentation and completed permitting procedures. Local co-funding is also available awaiting Programme’s findings on the adequacy of existing documentation and conceptualization for any new or improvement of any new river engineering designs.
Outcome 3: - Following the assessment of the river floods mitigation priorities (a Swiss expertise-supported process), the Programme developed comprehensive design guidelines (ToRs) and initiated the contracting of design engineers for three critical river sections: upper Vardar River (two sections, one in the Municipality of Gostivar and another in the Municipality of Jegunovce) and Bogovinjska River (Municipality of Bogovinje). - The Project launched the urban runoff management study for Tetovo and Gostivar. As part of this study, the Programme will identify the critical infrastructure located in the high-risk zones along the main analyzed water courses. Such critical infrastructure (e.g., hospitals, schools, factories) is especially present in the two major urban centers of the region – Tetovo and Gostivar. Considering the current and likely future levels of protection in these flood risk zones, the Programme will design and implement flood proofing options for selected set of public buildings. This will be one of the Programme’s priorities in the upcoming months. - The Programme has facilitated a process of selection of public buildings for providing them with green roofs as one of the urban resilience building options. This activity targeted the densest urban centers Tetovo and Gostivar, as major urban sites and most dense area in the region, where other possibilities for retaining water and preventing urban flooding are limited. The first demonstration green roof was built on a school in Gostivar. All works were completed, and the intervention was co-funded by the municipality in amount of Approximately USD 107,000 - Considering the improved understanding of potential of green infrastructure (or combination of green and grey infrastructure) for urban runoff management among key stakeholders, the Programme conceptualized work necessary to develop management options for the densest urban parts of the cities of Tetovo and Gostivar.
Outcome 4: - The purpose of Programme activities under this Output is to strategize future risk mitigation investments through increased public expenditures in flood prevention, justifying a cost-effective use of increasingly scarce financial resources. Moreover, on the basis of the comprehensive flood risk assessments, and understanding mitigation potentials and limitations (i.e. residual risk), the Programme will consider a full range possible financial mechanisms for flood prevention, post-disaster response and risk transfer, aiming to improve the overall ability of institutions, businesses and communities to respond more resiliently to disastrous flood events in future. The Programme has continued its communication with the authorities, and financial institutions on introducing different financing instruments to improve risk management. The cooperation with the Ministry of Finance and the Insurance Supervision Agency is promising and opens possibility for significant positive influence on the financing side of DRR. To support these processes, the Programme is benefiting from the support of an international risk finance/transfer expert providing advisory services aiming at: a) conducting a comprehensive gap analysis targeting existing financial capacities and instruments vis-à-vis the actual needs based on the improved knowledge about country’s overall flood risk situation; b) outlining a roadmap for implementation of risk financing and risk transfer component of the Programme that will help position it optimally to utilize the momentum and fit to other ongoing and planned changes in the risk finance/transfer area.
Output 5: - Important international/Swiss experience is already being transferred to key beneficiaries through different consultancies and in the course of the stakeholder events (e.g., by the International Technical Adviser, and urban river flooding management experts from Switzerland).

Outcome 1: 1. The most significant studies launched by the Programme is the Feasibility study on basin-scale sediment management options for the Upper Vardar River Basin. The study analyzes possible sources of sediments (e.g. linear erosion processes, landslides), by combining relevant complementary methodologies and models and developing event-based scenarios with different probabilities. The aim is to identify the risks and to prioritize areas where sediment sources/processes need to be addressed and managed in a way to mitigate risks to acceptable levels. The study was completed and distributed in May. For the first time in the country, the analyses have applied the InSAR (Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar) methodology which provide a better understanding of the longer-term landscape/soil layer movements which may result in different hazardous situations (e.g., landslides, rockfalls). Considering the scale of potential threats from flooding and sediment transport processes at these several locations, the sediment management study identified 15-20 prioritized locations in total. Hazard and risk maps were produced, providing categorization of most important sediment sources in the Polog basin, and “relative” risk ranking, recommendations for erosion control and soil stabilization measures, suggested measures for the watersheds and has made selection of landslides for preparation of conceptual designs as final stage of the study. As identified at the first stage of the preparation, the Study confirmed the need for priority interventions in the village of Shipkovica, mitigation of river flooding in Bogovinjska River; mitigation of flood risks in Pena River; management sediment transport processes in Poroj River. 2. Activities for updating the Flood Risk Management Plan (FRMP) through interrelated research and feasibility assessments continued to enrich the existing planning base. The existing FRMP has served as a good basis for all the ongoing programme-backed research and studies (e.g., sediment management study, preparedness study, preparation of designs for critical riverbeds). Such approach was selected in order to ensure that FRMP remains the most important planning document for future flood risk mitigation interventions, and DRR priorities as part of the Basin’s development plans. First update of the FRMP is planned for end of 2021 when the consultant will incorporate all prepared studies and designs in the plan. The most substantial update is anticipated toward the end of the Programme that will set the risk mitigation and resilience building priorities for the upcoming years. 3. Network for resilient Polog In the reporting period, the project has continued to facilitate the frequent and closer cooperation between all municipalities in the region through supporting the operations of activities of the Network for Resilient Polog. Within this effort, three network meetings were organized in 2021. The Polog region or specifically Tetovo and Gostivar were heavily affected by COVID 19 outbreak so two out of three meetings were held online, while the one which take place in July was organized face-to-face in Tetovo. At the last meeting in Tetovo, the draft concept for the Early Warning System, as part of the Preparedness Study, was presented and discussed with the network members. It should be noted that most of the network members prefer to have the meeting in life instead on-line so if the epidemiological situation improves, next meeting that is planned to happen after the local elections, shall be organized face-to-face. A more concrete activities towards formalization of the inter-municipal body are scheduled for the following reporting period, but the upcoming local election might delay the planned activities.
Outcome 3: 1. Bogovinjska River in total 1,2 km Bogovinska river is one of the Upper Vardar River Basin watercourses with high risk from flooding. The Feasibility study and the proposed solution for intervention for Bogovinjska river was prepared in 2020 and the basic design was completed in this reporting period. The procedure for approvals of Urban Plans for infrastructure started in June and is expected to be finalized in September. Bogovinjska River project will be advertised for selection of contractor in September and the construction works are expected to start in November 2021. 2. Upper Vardar River in the Municipality of Gostivar and Jegunovce - Upper Vardar River in the Municipality of Gostivar The only regulated section of the Vardar river in the Municipality of Gostivar is the one within the City of Gostivar. It was constructed in 1970 and has length of some 6 kilometers. Downstream from the railway bridge in the City of Gostivar the riverbed is unregulated, causing frequent floods (almost every year) on the settlements and the agricultural land, while the main reason for overflowing is the narrowing of the natural river corridor with various infrastructural structures and of the deposited solid waste in the riverbed. The Feasibility study for this part of Upper Vardar is prepared and the best optional solution confirmed by the International consultant from Switzerland. The basic design is prepared and is in process of revision. It is expected that the basic design will be completed by December 2021. - Upper Vardar River in the Municipality of Jegunovce The Vardar river in Jagunovce has frequently overflowed in the area between villages of Tudence and Jegunovce, causing damages to populated areas and agricultural land. The project of adjusting the technical documentation for this section with length of about 7 kilometers, was commenced in 2020. The Feasibility study for this part of Upper Vardar is prepared and the best optional solution confirmed by the International consultant from Switzerland. The basic design is prepared and is in process of revision. It is expected that the basic design will be completed by December 2021.
3. Torrent Sipkovica covering 17ha The Shipkovica torrent is one the most notorious ones in the region, since during the not-so-distant floods, beside the considerable economic damage made, the flood proved to be lethal for the locals. In general, the regulation of the Shipkovica torrent activity addresses the area of the torrent length of some 3,6 kilometers, with a special emphasis on the 350-meters-long section of the torrent that runs thru the very village. The Sipkovica project is in advanced stage, the selection of contractor is completed, and the construction works is expected to start end of September i.e. once the Municipality of Tetovo issues a construction permit. Co-financing in 49% of the value of the construction works is provided by the Ministry of Environment, and the Cost Shearing Agreement signed. 4. The urban runoff management studies for Tetovo and Gostivar are completed, and the critical infrastructure located in the high-risk zones along the main water courses are identified. Such critical infrastructure (e.g., hospitals, schools, factories) is especially present in the two major urban centers of the region – Tetovo and Gostivar. 5. Presentation of the run-off studies in both Tetovo and Gostivar were conducted in June, and the feedback from the Municipalities is expecting in the next period. The two most critical interventions were identified at the hospitals and the Programme requested a thorough Scope of Work to be prepared for designing. As the Hospitals are part of the Tertial Health System in the country, the Ministry of Health will be approached to come to an agreement on the interventions needed. The Terms of reference for designing the interventions are in process of preparation. 6. Feasibility study for Poroj is also prepared and presented to the Programme experts for comments. It was agreed that Poroj will be the first case study for integrated development approach including water flow analysis, regulation of the sediment slides from the remote areas flowing towards Poroj and the land use and urban planning of the area. This will give the Programme clear picture of what is possible to implement within the existing local and regional regulations and will also emphasize the areas where intervention or harmonization of the regulation with the EU regulation is needed

Outcome 1: • LIDAR was prepared partnering with the Agency for Real State Cadaster in order to optimize use of resources for preparation of high-resolution digital terrain model for the entire river basin. The surveying was conducted by the use of LiDAR technology (Light Detection and Ranging) mounted on special aircraft. The new DTM will make the future flood risk assessment more accurate and will also provide foundation for a number of other important analyses and plans (e.g., general and detailed urban plans, infrastructure planning, water management, erosion modeling and control, landslide hazard and risk maps, urban runoff management studies, land-use planning, environmental impact assessment, natural resource management). • In order to update the erosion and landslide risk and hazard mapping exercise, the programme developed an innovative concept for studying sediment transport processes. A comprehensive feasibility study on basin-scale sediment management options for the Polog Region is carried to analyze all possible sources of sediments (e.g. linear erosion processes, landslides), by combining relevant complementary methodologies and models and developing event-based scenarios with different probabilities. Following the hazard mapping exercise (i.e. understanding of the physical sediment transport processes), the study will use detailed land-use data (for current and planned development) to identify risks and prioritize areas where sediment sources/processes need to be managed in a way to mitigate risks to acceptable levels. • On the first working session of the Network which was held on 29 January 2019, the Rules of procedure and the Handbook for the work of the Network were prepared and adopted. Five working sessions of the Network took place in 2019 and several workshops for strengthening the capacities of the members of the network were organized. • The Network facilitated the resource mobilization process at local level through finalizing the legal/procedural acts and incorporation of these commitments in the 2019 and 2020 municipal budgets. All nine municipalities signed an Agreement for joining funds though which they committed to allocate 1-3% of their budgets for the period 2018-2021. The overall idea is that municipalities ensure permanent funding of risk reduction and resilience building activities at basin-scale upon closure of the programme. Efforts are taken so that the current Network becomes a formal joint administration of all municipalities charged with responsibilities over disaster risk management, and overall environmental protection. • First-ever country-level effort to mainstream DRR and resilience building priorities into the General Urban Plan for the Polog’s largest urban area – the City of Tetovo was launched. In close partnership with the municipal administration, and with the support of the international expert specialized in development planning, urban design, spatial/land-use and urban planning, Mr. Mike Sharrocks identification of entry points for mainstreaming DRR priorities in the GUP,was done. Programme’s International Technical Adviser (Mr. Markus Zimmermann) further deepened and broadened the overall planning concept by incorporating the most contemporary resilience building principles as per international models and experiences from Switzerland. International expertise was engaged to review the current urban development and the associated challenges, review of legislation and urban planning methodologies, and providing guidance for improved urban planning in line with contemporary approaches and practices. Terms of References for the new GUP that provides the necessary guidance to the responsible planning entity – the State Agency for Spatial Planning was prepared The main funding for the new GUP has been provided by the central government and the programme support will ensure that this process results in a model GUP which can be followed nation-wide. • Revision of the existing municipal flood management plans is initiated in order to harmonize them with the objectives of the FRMP, creating by the necessary local-level planning base for coordinated flood risk mitigation action. This effort will result in a consolidated national-level methodology for municipal flood management planning which is currently missing in the country. The need for preparation of such plans is defined in the Law on Waters, but no secondary legislation and/or previously adopted methodology is in place to support this. This activity is considered particularly important for the future, as municipalities tend to develop these plans without sufficient understanding of the upstream-downstream relations in flood management, which often leads to a situation in which the measures taken on the territory of one upstream municipality increase the flood risk in downstream communities. Support is provided to municipalities to consolidate and interlink their emergency response plans (e.g., crisis management and protection and rescue plans) in line with the findings of all relevant ongoing and future studies. A consolidated national-level methodology for developing municipal operative flood defense plans is being finalized.
Outcome 3: • FRMP identified the most critical river sections in the basin when it comes to flood risk for which there are limited management options (e.g., limitations imposed by urbanization in the floodplains/river corridors). These interventions are considered the highest priority for the authorities having in mind the magnitude of existing risks. For part of these interventions, municipalities had already prepared detailed technical documentation and completed permitting procedures. The project engaged Swiss expertise to prepare design concepts, and design guidelines/specifications for adjustment of existing designs for regulation of Vardar River (Jegunovce section), and Bogovinjska Reka (Bogovinje and Brvenica municipalities) as well as to provide guidelines for preparation of new technical design for Vardar River along the Gostivar section. Design guidelines will be used as foundation for preparation of TORs for development of detailed technical documentation for ecosystem-oriented urban river flood management design for Vardar River downstream the City of Gostivar as well as for adjustment of existing designs for regulation of Vardar River (Jegunovce section), and Bogovinjska Reka (Bogovinje and Brvenica municipalities). The guidelines will provide contemporary approaches (e.g., nature-based solutions, Eco-DRR, etc.), mindful of the multitude of constraints imposed by the local setting. • Preliminary activities for preparation of the Terms of reference for the feasibility study for urban runoff management (targeting Tetovo and Gostivar) were carried out. The study will help address the growing challenge of pluvial flooding in an urban context, as well as urban runoff (stormwater) due to the uncontrolled urbanization and conversion of natural land for different development purposes As part of the assignment design and implementation of specific mitigation measures mostly in the highly urbanized parts of the region will be done. • Identification of critical infrastructure located in the high-risk zones along the main analyzed water courses was done. Such critical infrastructure (e.g., hospitals, schools, factories) is especially present in the two major urban centers of the region – Tetovo and Gostivar. Considering the current and likely future levels of protection in these flood risk zones, the project will design and implement flood proofing options for selected set of public buildings. In line with the urban resilience concept, and wishing to demonstrate contemporary concepts, the project has facilitated a process of selection of public buildings that will be provided with green roofs in the densest urban centers Tetovo and Gostivar.The first demonstration green roof is built onto a major school center in Gostivar. This intervention was co-funded by the municipality itself considering the importance of the school as well as the social and political pressure given the poor conditions for pupils. This joint effort helped realize a multi-benefit resilience building initiative which can be replicated elsewhere in the region. The municipal co-funding in amount of app. 107,000 USD was allocated from the budget dedicated to risk reduction and resilience building. Design activities are underway to secure a local kindergarten in Tetovo with a similar roof.
Outcome 4: • The sociological survey that was carried out generated useful information that facilitated discussions on the improvements of the financing mechanisms, including insurance. This research analyzed the interest of families living in at-risk areas in risk transfer schemes and their willingness to insure their property if they get subsidies from the government. Nearly half of the citizens did express interest to insure their property if there is certain governmental subsidy. International Risk Financing and Risk Transfer Mechanisms Expert was engaged to provide advisory services to support the implementation of the flood risk financing and risk transfer component of the programme. Specifically, the expert will prepare a comprehensive national level gap analysis targeting existing financial capacities and instruments vis-à-vis the actual needs based on the improved knowledge about country’s overall flood risk situation (to be completed as part of a parallel processed supported by the programme). Based on this analysis, the expert will be expected to outline a national level roadmap for risk financing and risk transfer component of the programme that will help position it optimally to utilize the momentum and fit to other ongoing and planned changes in the risk finance/transfer area. The project has established initial cooperation with the authorities, and financial institutions on introducing different financing instruments to improve risk management. • The International Risk Financing and Risk Transfer Mechanisms Expert engaged for support the implementation of the flood risk financing and risk transfer component of the project reviewed best practices/models for disaster risk management including financial instruments and corresponding institutional setup. As part of the assignment, a roadmap of risk financing and risk transfer mechanisms is being developed which will position the project in the national landscape concerning risk finance and risk transfer and enable it to support national processes in identifying an optimal risk financing scenario at local (Polog region) and national level and strengthen the existing institutions in this regard. • Since this reform is highly dependent on high-level political will and profound understanding among the key policy- and decision makers about current and future risks, the project has adopted an approach to facilitate a multifaceted policy dialogue process. As part of the Roadmap of risk financing and risk transfer mechanisms, the International Risk Financing and Risk Transfer Mechanisms Expert is preparing an Outline of a policy dialogue process with the national regulatory and policy making institutions, local institutions and key service providers. Initial cooperation with the authorities, and financial institutions on introducing different financing instruments to improve risk management is established. The focus on this early-stage cooperation has been on generating knowledge and exploring possibilities for joining efforts to reduce long-term risks to people and property from floods and facilitate post-disaster recovery efforts through improved financing. The cooperation with the Ministry of Finance and the Insurance Supervision Agency is promising and opens possibility significant positive influence on the financing side of DRR. Outcome 5: • for inter-university exchanges on issues of relevance through partnership of Swiss and Macedonian research and educational institutions are considered. Discussions are underway with the Faculty of Civil Engineering and Faculty of Forestry which expressed interested in joint research and training. Details on this will be elaborated in the upcoming period as they largely depend on the availability of young researchers with interests in DRR/flood risk management and other related fields. • The project carried preliminary activities in establishing connections with relevant Swiss partners at central and local level government with relevant experience (e.g., DRR, flood risk management, regulation of torrential streams, early warning systems, and insurance), in order support a study visit for networking and transfer of knowledge of responsible Macedonian institutions and relevant Swiss partners.
